content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are fairly open to taking risks but still prefer to assess the situation carefully. You are not reckless, but you are not overly cautious either. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Given that my previous strategy was to start with 'R', and I saw that my opponent did the same, I might consider sticking to this strategy for now. However, knowing that both of us are not reckless or overly cautious, it's likely that we will adopt a mixed strategy over time to avoid predictability. For the next round, I will choose 'R' again. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

If my opponent chooses 'B' when I pick 'R', it means that they might have a mixed strategy, or perhaps they saw that I was sticking to 'R' and decided to take advantage of it. Since I know now that my opponent can choose 'B' when I pick 'R', I should adjust my strategy accordingly to avoid getting zero payoff every time this situation occurs. For the next round, I will choose 'B'. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent picked 'R' when I picked 'B', and I got a payoff of 40$, it suggests that my opponent might not be sticking to a strict mixed strategy, or they made a mistake. To exploit this situation, I will stick to 'B' for the next round as well, hoping that my opponent will again choose 'R'. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

If my opponent chooses 'B' when I do, we both get a payoff of 20$. This is a Nash Equilibrium, as neither player can increase their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy. Since this outcome was already observed in the previous round, it seems that my opponent and I have converged on a stable strategy. At this point, I would continue with 'B' for the next rounds as well. {B}
